title: Do editors call scientists and doctors by their first names? - Quora

response.answer_text: When we were producing 50 books a year, many of them by scientists and physicians, we worked closely with authors on their books for major publishers. In general, we addressed them by their first names while working with them, both in emails and in phone conversations. There’s still an aura of importance when someone is doing a book for a publisher with a famous name. In the early 1990s we worked on a book by a physician who was then Dean of the Harvard Medical School. The publisher was Addison Wesley. It was amazing how quickly we were able to get this guy on the phone to talk about his book. I sometimes imagined what it might have been like to be one of his patients who wanted to talk to him. But U.S. business culture is very informal. When Wall Street financiers use phrases like “cock blocking” and call the president “Don” it should be no surprise that scientists and doctors are also called by their first names.

Generally speaking, editors who don’t know me use the default letter templates in their editing systems, and call me “Dr. Robson” or “Dr. Barbara Robson.” Editors who do know me sometimes use the same templates (because it is quicker and easier), and sometimes take the time to personalise their letters more, in which case they usually use my first name. As an editor myself, I adopt the same approach. Using a title is polite if you don’t really know your correspondent and they have not introduced themselves by their first name. Using a first name is, in my culture at least, more polite in the case of someone with whom you are on friendly terms.

Things are becoming informal in some countries, but I believe it is still customary in most countries, particularly in early contacts if they are not already friends, for each to use the other’s surname.
